article:
2023–24 Saudi Pro League

The 2023–24 Saudi Pro League, also known as the Saudi Pro League (SPL), is the 47th season of Saudi Arabia's top division of football. The season will feature 18 teams competing in a double round-robin format, with the top teams qualifying for the AFC Champions League and the bottom teams facing relegation to the First Division League.

# Overview

## Changes

The 2023–24 season will see several changes from the previous season. The league will feature 18 teams, up from 16 teams in the previous season. The Saudi Arabian Football Federation (SAFF) has also introduced several rule changes, including the use of video assistant referees (VARs) and the introduction of a new format for the league's playoff system.

## Record

The 2023–24 season is expected to break several records, including the number of goals scored and the number of teams competing in the league. The season will also feature several high-profile matches, including the Saudi El Clásico between Al-Hilal and Al-Nassr.

# Teams

## Teams who were promoted to the Pro League

The following teams were promoted to the Pro League for the 2023–24 season:

* Al-Ahli
* Al-Qadsiah
* Al-Riyadh
* Al-Shabab
* Al-Taawoun

## Teams who were relegated to the FD League

The following teams were relegated to the First Division League for the 2023–24 season:

* Al-Batin
* Al-Jabalain
* Al-Khaleej
* Al-Shoulla

## Stadiums

The following stadiums will be used during the 2023–24 season:

* King Fahd International Stadium (Al-Hilal and Al-Nassr)
* King Abdullah Sports City (Al-Ahli and Al-Ittihad)
* Prince Faisal bin Fahd Stadium (Al-Shabab and Al-Hilal)
* Prince Abdullah bin Jalawi Stadium (Al-Qadsiah and Al-Fateh)
* King Saud University Stadium (Al-Taawoun and Al-Riyadh)

article:
Associate international cricket in 2022–23

The 2022–23 season of associate international cricket is the eighth season of associate international cricket since the International Cricket Council (ICC) restructured the calendar of international cricket in 2015. The season starts in September 2022 and ends in April 2023. A total of 52 teams, 22 full members and 30 associate members, are scheduled to compete in 24 tournaments, playing a total of 144 matches.

# Season overview

The season includes several ICC-organised tournaments, including the ICC T20 World Cup EAP Qualifier A, ICC T20 World Cup EAP Qualifier B, ICC T20 World Cup Africa Qualifier A, ICC T20 World Cup Africa Qualifier B, ICC Men's T20 World Cup Americas Sub-Regional Qualifier, ICC Men's T20 World Cup Asia Sub-Regional Qualifier, ICC Women's T20 World Cup Qualifier, and the ICC Men's Cricket World Cup Qualifier Play-off. Other major tournaments include the ACC Men's Challenger Cup, ACC Men's Premier Cup, and the Asia Cup Qualifier.

# September

## 2022–23 ICC T20 World Cup EAP Qualifier A

The 2022–23 ICC T20 World Cup EAP Qualifier A was a T20I tournament played in Fiji in September 2022. The tournament featured four teams: Fiji, Samoa, Tonga, and Vanuatu. Vanuatu won the tournament, beating Fiji by 2 wickets in the final.

## 2022 United Arab Emirates Women's Quadrangular Series

The 2022 United Arab Emirates Women's Quadrangular Series was a women's T20I tournament played in the United Arab Emirates in September 2022. The tournament featured four teams: Bahrain, Oman, Qatar, and the United Arab Emirates. The United Arab Emirates won the tournament, beating Bahrain by 7 wickets in the final.

## 2022 ACA Africa T20 Cup

The 2022 ACA Africa T20 Cup was a T20I tournament played in South Africa in September 2022. The tournament featured eight teams: Botswana, Cameroon, Eswatini, Ghana, Kenya, Lesotho, Malawi, and Mozambique. Ghana won the tournament, beating Cameroon by 8 wickets in the final.

## 2022 ICC Women's T20 World Cup Qualifier

The 2022 ICC Women's T20 World Cup Qualifier was a women's T20I tournament played in Abu Dhabi and Dubai in September 2022. The tournament featured eight teams: Bangladesh, Ireland, Scotland, Thailand, the United Arab Emirates, the United States, Zimbabwe, and Papua New Guinea. The top two teams, Ireland and Zimbabwe, qualified for the 2023 ICC Women's T20 World Cup.

# October

## 2022 Women's Pacific Cup

The 2022 Women's Pacific Cup was a women's T20I tournament played in Vanuatu in October 2022. The tournament featured four teams: Fiji, Papua New Guinea, Samoa, and Vanuatu. Papua New Guinea won the tournament, beating Vanuatu by 8 wickets in the final.

## Indonesia in Japan

The Indonesian women's cricket team toured Japan in October 2022, playing a series of three women's T20I matches. Japan won the series 2-1.

## 2022 Women's South American Cricket Championship

The 2022 Women's South American Cricket Championship was a women's T20I tournament played in Brazil in October 2022. The tournament featured four teams: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, and Peru. Brazil won the tournament, beating Argentina by 7 wickets in the final.

## 2022–23 ICC T20 World Cup EAP Qualifier B

The 2022–23 ICC T20 World Cup EAP Qualifier B was a T20I tournament played in Vanuatu in October 2022. The tournament featured four teams: Cook Islands, Fiji, Samoa, and Vanuatu. Vanuatu won the tournament, beating Fiji by 8 wickets in the final.

## 2022 Men's South American Cricket Championship

The 2022 Men's South American Cricket Championship was a T20I tournament played in Brazil in October 2022. The tournament featured four teams: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, and Peru. Argentina won the tournament, beating Brazil by 4 wickets in the final.

## Hong Kong women in Japan

The Hong Kong women's cricket team toured Japan in October 2022, playing a series of three women's T20I matches. Hong Kong won the series 2-1.

## Rwanda in Tanzania

The Rwandan women's cricket team toured Tanzania in October 2022, playing a series of three women's T20I matches. Tanzania won the series 2-1.

# November

## Singapore women in Indonesia

The Singaporean women's cricket team toured Indonesia in November 2022, playing a series of three women's T20I matches. Singapore won the series 2-1.

## 2022–23 Spain Tri-Nation Series

The 2022–23 Spain Tri-Nation Series was a T20I tournament played in Spain in November 2022. The tournament featured three teams: Germany, Italy, and Spain. Spain won the tournament, beating Italy by 5 wickets in the final.

## 2022 Spain Women's Pentangular Series

The 2022 Spain Women's Pentangular Series was a women's T20I tournament played in Spain in November 2022. The tournament featured five teams: Austria, Belgium, Germany, Italy, and Spain. Germany won the tournament, beating Austria by 8 wickets in the final.

## 2022 Desert Cup T20I Series

The 2022 Desert Cup T20I Series was a T20I tournament played in Oman in November 2022. The tournament featured four teams: Bahrain, Oman, Saudi Arabia, and the United Arab Emirates. Oman won the tournament, beating Bahrain by 7 wickets in the final.

## 2022–23 ICC T20 World Cup Africa Qualifier A

The 2022–23 ICC T20 World Cup Africa Qualifier A was a T20I tournament played in Rwanda in November 2022. The tournament featured eight teams: Botswana, Cameroon, Eswatini, Ghana, Kenya, Lesotho, Malawi, and Rwanda. Kenya won the tournament, beating Ghana by 6 wickets in the final.

# December

## 2022–23 ICC T20 World Cup Africa Qualifier B

The 2022–23 ICC T20 World Cup Africa Qualifier B was a T20I tournament played in South Africa in December 2022. The tournament featured eight teams: Botswana, Eswatini, Ghana, Kenya, Lesotho, Malawi, Mozambique, and Rwanda. Ghana won the tournament, beating Botswana by 8 wickets in the final.

## 2022 East Africa T20 Series

The 2022 East Africa T20 Series was a T20I tournament played in Tanzania in December 2022. The tournament featured four teams: Kenya, Rwanda, Tanzania, and Uganda. Kenya won the tournament, beating Uganda by 6 wickets in the final.

## 2022–23 Kenya Women's Quadrangular Series

The 2022–23 Kenya Women's Quadrangular Series was a women's T20I tournament played in Kenya in December 2022. The tournament featured four teams: Bangladesh, Kenya, Nepal, and Zimbabwe. Bangladesh won the tournament, beating Nepal by 7 wickets in the final.

## 2022–23 Malaysia Quadrangular Series

The 2022–23 Malaysia Quadrangular Series was a T20I tournament played in Malaysia in December 2022. The tournament featured four teams: India, Malaysia, Nepal, and Oman. India won the tournament, beating Oman by 8 wickets in the final.

The Philippine women's cricket team toured Cambodia in December 2022, playing a series of three women's T20I matches. Cambodia won the series 2-1.

The Bermudian women's cricket team toured Argentina in February 2023, playing a series of three women's T20I matches. Argentina won the series 2-1.

The 2023 ACC Men's Challenger Cup was a T20I tournament played in the United Arab Emirates in February 2023. The tournament featured eight teams: Bahrain, Bhutan, Iran, Kuwait, Maldives, Oman, Qatar, and Saudi Arabia. Oman won the tournament, beating Bahrain by 6 wickets in the final.

## Isle of Man in Spain

The Isle of Man women's cricket team toured Spain in February 2023, playing a series of three women's T20I matches. Spain won the series 2-1.

## 2023 ICC T20 World Cup Americas Sub-Regional Qualifier

The 2023 ICC T20 World Cup Americas Sub-Regional Qualifier was a T20I tournament played in Argentina in February 2023. The tournament featured four teams: Argentina, Bermuda, Canada, and the United States. Canada won the tournament, beating Argentina by 4 wickets in the final.

# March

## 2022–23 Hong Kong Quadrangular Series

The 2022–23 Hong Kong Quadrangular Series was a T20I tournament played in Hong Kong in March 2023. The tournament featured four teams: Hong Kong, Italy, Malaysia, and Oman. Hong Kong won the tournament, beating Malaysia by 7 wickets in the final.

## 2023 Pacific Island Cricket Challenge (Men)

The 2023 Pacific Island Cricket Challenge (Men) was a T20I tournament played in Vanuatu in March 2023. The tournament featured six teams: Fiji, New Caledonia, Niue, Samoa, Tonga, and Vanuatu. Vanuatu won the tournament, beating Samoa by 8 wickets in the final.

## 2023 Pacific Island Cricket Challenge (Women)

The 2023 Pacific Island Cricket Challenge (Women) was a women's T20I tournament played in Vanuatu in March 2023. The tournament featured six teams: Fiji, New Caledonia, Niue, Samoa, Tonga, and Vanuatu. Vanuatu won the tournament, beating Samoa by 7 wickets in the final.

## 2023 Nigeria Invitational Women's T20I Tournament

The 2023 Nigeria Invitational Women's T20I Tournament was a women's T20I tournament played in Nigeria in March 2023. The tournament featured four teams: Ghana, Kenya, Nigeria, and Rwanda. Ghana won the tournament, beating Kenya by 4 wickets in the final.

# April

## Gibraltar in Portugal

The Gibraltarian women's cricket team toured Portugal in April 2023, playing a series of three women's T20I matches. Portugal won the series 2-1.

## 2023 ACC Men's Premier Cup

The 2023 ACC Men's Premier Cup was a T20I tournament played in the United Arab Emirates in April 2023. The tournament featured eight teams: Bahrain, Bhutan, Iran, Kuwait, Maldives, Oman, Qatar, and Saudi Arabia. Oman won the tournament, beating Bahrain by 5 wickets in the final.

## 2023 Victoria Series

The 2023 Victoria Series was a T20I tournament played in Hong Kong in April 2023. The tournament featured four teams: Hong Kong, Italy, Malaysia, and Oman. Hong Kong won the tournament, beating Malaysia by 8 wickets in the final.

## 2023 Capricorn Women's Quadrangular Series

The 2023 Capricorn Women's Quadrangular Series was a women's T20I tournament played in Botswana in April 2023. The tournament featured four teams: Botswana, Mozambique, Namibia, and Zimbabwe. Zimbabwe won the tournament, beating Namibia by 7 wickets in the final.

2023–24 UEFA Champions League

The 2023–24 UEFA Champions League is the 69th season of Europe's premier club football tournament organized by UEFA, and the 32nd season since it was renamed from the European Champion Clubs' Cup to the UEFA Champions League.

#Association team allocation

##Association ranking

For the 2023–24 UEFA Champions League, the associations were allocated places according to their 2022 UEFA country coefficients, which took into account their performance in European competitions from 2017–18 to 2021–22.

##Distribution

In the 2023–24 UEFA Champions League, the following changes were made to the access list:

* The top four associations (Spain, England, Germany, and Italy) each had four teams qualify directly for the group stage.
* The associations ranked fifth to sixth (France and Portugal) each had three teams qualify directly for the group stage.
* The associations ranked seventh to tenth (Netherlands, Russia, Belgium, and Austria) each had two teams qualify directly for the group stage.
* The associations ranked eleventh to fifteen (Scotland, Ukraine, Czech Republic, Turkey, and Greece) each had one team qualify directly for the group stage.
* The associations ranked sixteenth to fifty-four had one team qualify for the qualifying rounds.

##Teams

A total of 79 teams from 54 UEFA member associations participated in the 2023–24 UEFA Champions League. The teams were:

* The top four teams from the associations ranked first to fourth (Spain, England, Germany, and Italy)
* The top three teams from the associations ranked fifth to sixth (France and Portugal)
* The top two teams from the associations ranked seventh to tenth (Netherlands, Russia, Belgium, and Austria)
* The top team from the associations ranked eleventh to fifteen (Scotland, Ukraine, Czech Republic, Turkey, and Greece)
* The winners of the associations ranked sixteenth to fifty-four
* The winners of the 2022–23 UEFA Champions League and the 2022–23 UEFA Europa League

#Schedule

The schedule of the 2023–24 UEFA Champions League was as follows:

* Preliminary round: June 2023
* First qualifying round: July 2023
* Second qualifying round: July 2023
* Third qualifying round: August 2023
* Play-off round: August 2023
* Group stage: September 2023 to December 2023
* Knockout phase: February 2024 to May 2024
* Final: May 2024

#Qualifying rounds

The qualifying rounds were played as a knockout tournament, with each tie played over two legs (home and away).

##Preliminary round

The preliminary round was played on June 2023. The four teams that participated were the champions of the associations ranked fifty-second to fifty-four.

##First qualifying round

The first qualifying round was played on July 2023. The teams that participated were the champions of the associations ranked sixteenth to fifty-first.

##Second qualifying round

The second qualifying round was played on July 2023. The teams that participated were the winners of the first qualifying round and the champions of the associations ranked seventh to fifteenth.

##Third qualifying round

The third qualifying round was played on August 2023. The teams that participated were the winners of the second qualifying round and the teams that finished third in the associations ranked first to sixth.

#Play-off round

The play-off round was played on August 2023. The teams that participated were the winners of the third qualifying round and the teams that finished fourth in the associations ranked first to fourth.

#Group stage

The group stage was played from September 2023 to December 2023. The teams were divided into eight groups of four teams each. The teams played each other twice (home and away).

##Group A

Group A consisted of the teams from the associations ranked first to eighth.

#Knockout phase

The knockout phase was played from February 2024 to May 2024. The teams that finished first and second in each group qualified for the knockout phase.

##Bracket

The knockout phase was played as a single-elimination tournament. The teams that participated were the winners and runners-up of each group.

##Round of 16

The round of 16 was played on February 2024. The teams that participated were the winners and runners-up of each group.

##Quarter-finals

The quarter-finals were played on March 2024. The teams that participated were the winners of the round of 16.

##Semi-finals

The semi-finals were played on April 2024. The teams that participated were the winners of the quarter-finals.

##Final

The final was played on May 2024. The teams that participated were the winners of the semi-finals.

2022 Visit by Nancy Pelosi to Taiwan

The 2022 visit by Nancy Pelosi to Taiwan was a highly publicized and contentious trip made by the Speaker of the United States House of Representatives, Nancy Pelosi, to Taiwan from August 2 to 3, 2022. The visit was part of a broader tour of Asia, which also included stops in Singapore, Malaysia, Japan, and South Korea. The trip was widely seen as a significant development in the complex and sensitive relationship between the United States, Taiwan, and the People's Republic of China (PRC).

# Background

Taiwan, officially known as the Republic of China (ROC), has been governed separately from mainland China since the end of the Chinese Civil War in 1949. The PRC claims Taiwan as its own territory and has not ruled out the use of force to achieve reunification. The United States, while not officially recognizing Taiwan as a sovereign state, has maintained a close relationship with the island through the Taiwan Relations Act, which provides for the sale of military equipment and other forms of cooperation.

In recent years, tensions between the United States and the PRC have increased, with the two powers competing for influence in the Asia-Pacific region. The visit by Pelosi, who is second in line to the presidency, was seen as a significant gesture of support for Taiwan and a challenge to the PRC's claims of sovereignty over the island.

# Visit

Pelosi's visit to Taiwan was announced on July 31, 2022, after weeks of speculation and warnings from the PRC. The trip was initially planned for April 2022, but was postponed due to a COVID-19 outbreak in Taiwan. The visit was part of a broader tour of Asia, which also included stops in Singapore, Malaysia, Japan, and South Korea.

Pelosi arrived in Taiwan on the evening of August 2, 2022, and was greeted by Taiwanese Foreign Minister Joseph Wu and other high-ranking officials. During her visit, Pelosi met with Taiwanese President Tsai Ing-wen and other senior officials, and delivered a speech to the Taiwanese parliament.

In her speech, Pelosi praised Taiwan's commitment to democracy and human rights, and reaffirmed the United States' support for the island. She also called on Taiwan to continue to strengthen its defenses and diversify its economy.

# Reactions

## United States

The visit was widely supported by members of Congress and other U.S. officials. The White House stated that Pelosi's visit was "consistent with our One China policy" and that the United States would continue to support Taiwan's participation in international organizations.

Some U.S. politicians, including Senator Tom Cotton and Representative Mike Gallagher, praised Pelosi's visit as a strong show of support for Taiwan. Others, including Senator Bernie Sanders and Representative Ro Khanna, expressed concerns about the potential consequences of the visit.

## People's Republic of China

The PRC strongly condemned Pelosi's visit, calling it a "serious violation of the One China principle" and a "major provocation" against China's sovereignty. The PRC's Foreign Ministry stated that the visit would have "serious consequences" for relations between the United States and China.

### Hong Kong

The Hong Kong government also condemned Pelosi's visit, calling it a "serious challenge" to the PRC's sovereignty and a " threat to the stability of Hong Kong".

### Sanctions

The PRC imposed sanctions on Pelosi and her immediate family members, freezing their assets in China and banning them from entering the country.

## International

### Intergovernmental organizations

The United Nations did not issue a statement on Pelosi's visit, but the UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres called for calm and restraint in the region.

The European Union stated that it was "concerned" about the tensions in the Taiwan Strait and called for a peaceful resolution.

### Nations

Japan, a key U.S. ally in the region, expressed concern about the tensions and called for calm.

South Korea, which had just hosted Pelosi on her Asia tour, stated that it was "closely watching" the situation and called for a peaceful resolution.

Russia, which has been a key supporter of the PRC in recent years, condemned Pelosi's visit as a "provocation" against China's sovereignty.

# Interpretations and popular response

Pelosi's visit was widely seen as a significant development in the complex and sensitive relationship between the United States, Taiwan, and the PRC. Some analysts interpreted the visit as a show of support for Taiwan and a challenge to the PRC's claims of sovereignty over the island.

Others saw the visit as a calculated move by the United States to demonstrate its commitment to the Asia-Pacific region and to counter the PRC's growing influence.

The visit also sparked a lively debate on social media, with some users praising Pelosi's visit as a strong show of support for Taiwan, while others expressed concerns about the potential consequences.

# Aftermath

The visit by Pelosi to Taiwan marked a significant escalation in tensions between the United States and the PRC. The PRC's response, including the imposition of sanctions and the conduct of military exercises, highlighted the complexity and sensitivity of the relationship between the two powers.

The visit also underscored the importance of Taiwan in the Asia-Pacific region and the need for a peaceful resolution to the tensions in the Taiwan Strait.

2022 United Kingdom heatwaves

The 2022 United Kingdom heatwaves were a series of severe heatwaves that affected the United Kingdom in June, July, and August 2022. The heatwaves brought record-breaking temperatures, drought, and wildfires to the country, causing significant disruptions to daily life and the economy.

# June heatwave

The first heatwave of the summer began in mid-June, with temperatures rising above 30°C (86°F) across much of the country. The heatwave was caused by a high-pressure system that had been building over the UK for several days, bringing warm air from the continent. The warm weather was welcomed by many, who had been experiencing a cool and wet spring.

## Impact on resorts

The June heatwave had a significant impact on resorts across the UK, particularly those in coastal areas. Many resorts reported a surge in bookings, as people took advantage of the warm weather to enjoy the beach and other outdoor activities. However, some resorts struggled to cope with the increased demand, leading to shortages of accommodation and amenities.

# July heatwave

The July heatwave was even more severe than the June heatwave, with temperatures reaching record-breaking levels across the UK. The heatwave was caused by a combination of a high-pressure system and a heatwave from the continent, which brought extremely hot air to the UK. Temperatures rose above 35°C (95°F) in many areas, with some parts of the country experiencing temperatures above 40°C (104°F).

## Impact

The July heatwave had a significant impact on the UK, with widespread disruptions to daily life and the economy.

### Transport

The heatwave caused significant disruptions to transport networks across the UK. Many roads melted in the heat, causing traffic congestion and accidents. Rail networks were also affected, with some trains being cancelled or delayed due to the heat. Air travel was also disrupted, with some flights being cancelled or delayed due to the heat.

### Retail

The heatwave had a significant impact on retail businesses across the UK. Many shops and supermarkets reported a surge in sales of cooling products, such as fans and air conditioners. However, some businesses struggled to cope with the increased demand, leading to shortages of certain products.

### Berry farming

The heatwave had a devastating impact on berry farming in the UK. Many berry crops were damaged or destroyed by the heat, leading to a shortage of fresh berries. The heatwave also affected the quality of the berries, making them more susceptible to disease and pests.

### Seaside resorts

The heatwave had a significant impact on seaside resorts across the UK. Many resorts reported a surge in bookings, as people took advantage of the warm weather to enjoy the beach and other outdoor activities. However, some resorts struggled to cope with the increased demand, leading to shortages of accommodation and amenities.

### Utilities

The heatwave caused significant strains on utility companies across the UK. Many people used more water and electricity than usual, leading to shortages and disruptions to services.

## Aftermath

The aftermath of the July heatwave saw widespread criticism of the government's response to the crisis. Many people felt that the government had not done enough to prepare for the heatwave, leading to unnecessary suffering and disruptions.

# August heatwave

The August heatwave was less severe than the July heatwave, but still caused significant disruptions to daily life and the economy.

## Rain

The August heatwave was accompanied by heavy rainfall in some parts of the UK, which caused flooding and disruptions to transport networks.

## Impact

### Gardening

# Drought

The 2022 UK heatwaves were accompanied by a severe drought, which affected many parts of the country. The drought had a significant impact on agriculture, with many crops being damaged or destroyed by the lack of water.

# Wildfires

The 2022 UK heatwaves were also accompanied by a series of devastating wildfires, which affected many parts of the country. The wildfires were caused by a combination of the heat and dry conditions, and were fueled by strong winds.

# Meteorology

The 2022 UK heatwaves were caused by a combination of meteorological factors, including high-pressure systems and heatwaves from the continent. The heatwaves were also fueled by climate change, which is causing temperatures to rise globally.

# Media coverage

article:
Hogwarts Legacy
================

Hogwarts Legacy is an action role-playing video game set in the Harry Potter universe. Developed by Avalanche Software and published by Warner Bros. Games, the game allows players to create their own wizard and embark on a journey through the magical world. With its rich storyline, engaging gameplay, and immersive setting, Hogwarts Legacy offers an unforgettable experience for fans of the Harry Potter series.

Gameplay
---------

In Hogwarts Legacy, players take on the role of a young wizard starting their fifth year at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry. The game features an open-world setting, allowing players to explore the castle, its grounds, and the surrounding areas. Players can master various magical spells, potions, and abilities, which can be used to solve puzzles, overcome obstacles, and engage in combat.

The gameplay revolves around completing quests, attending classes, and interacting with non-playable characters (NPCs). Players can choose to specialize in specific magical disciplines, such as Charms, Transfiguration, or Herbology, which will influence their abilities and playstyle. The game also features a dynamic dueling system, allowing players to engage in magical combat with other wizards.

Throughout the game, players will uncover a rich narrative that explores the history of the wizarding world and the secrets of Hogwarts. The story is heavily influenced by the player's choices, which will impact the fate of the wizarding world and the characters within it.

Synopsis
--------

### Setting and Characters

Hogwarts Legacy is set in the late 19th century, approximately 100 years before the events of the main Harry Potter series. The game takes place at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry, with its iconic castle, grounds, and surrounding areas. Players will encounter a range of characters, including professors, students, and magical creatures, each with their own unique personalities and storylines.

The game features a diverse cast of characters, including both familiar faces from the Harry Potter series and new, original characters. Players will interact with characters such as Professors Sharp, Weasley, and Vector, as well as other students and wizards who will aid or hinder their progress.

### Plot

The story of Hogwarts Legacy revolves around an ancient evil that threatens the wizarding world. Players take on the role of a young wizard who possesses a unique ability that makes them the key to unlocking the secrets of the ancient magic.

As players progress through the game, they will uncover a rich narrative that explores the history of the wizarding world, the secrets of Hogwarts, and the true nature of the ancient evil. The story is heavily influenced by the player's choices, which will impact the fate of the wizarding world and the characters within it.

Throughout the game, players will encounter various plot twists and turns, including unexpected alliances, hidden agendas, and surprising revelations. The story is designed to be engaging and immersive, with a deep narrative that will keep players invested in the world and its characters.

Development
------------

### Music

The music in Hogwarts Legacy was composed by J Scott Riegel, Peter Murray, and Chuck Myers. The soundtrack features a range of magical and atmospheric tracks, including orchestral pieces, choral works, and instrumental compositions. The music is designed to be immersive and engaging, with a rich, cinematic sound that complements the game's narrative and gameplay.

### Release

Hogwarts Legacy was released on February 10, 2023, for PC, PlayStation 4, PlayStation 5, Xbox One, Xbox Series X/S, and Nintendo Switch. The game was developed by Avalanche Software and published by Warner Bros. Games.

### Additional Content

Hogwarts Legacy features a range of additional content, including downloadable content (DLC) packs, free updates, and online features. The game's DLC packs will add new storylines, characters, and gameplay mechanics, while the free updates will include new features, bug fixes, and performance improvements.

The game also features online features, including leaderboards, challenges, and social sharing options. Players can share their progress, compete with friends, and showcase their magical abilities.

Reception
----------

### Critical Response

Hogwarts Legacy received generally positive reviews from critics, with praise for its engaging gameplay, immersive setting, and rich narrative. Reviewers praised the game's open-world design, magical combat system, and character customization options.

However, some critics noted that the game's story was somewhat predictable, and that the combat system could be repetitive at times. Others criticized the game's graphics and performance, citing some minor issues with framerate and texture rendering.

### Sales

Hogwarts Legacy was a commercial success, with strong sales across all platforms. The game debuted at number one on the UK charts, and reached the top five in the US and other major markets.

### Accolades

Hogwarts Legacy received several awards and nominations, including a nomination for Best RPG at the 2023 Game Awards. The game also received praise from fans and critics alike, with many considering it one of the best games of 2023.

The Masked Singer (Australian TV series) Season 4
=====================================================

The fourth season of the Australian version of The Masked Singer premiered on 7 August 2022, on Network 10. The season featured a new cast of contestants, a returning panel of judges, and a new host.

Production
------------

The season was produced by Warner Bros. International Television Production Australia and was filmed at the Docklands Studios Melbourne in Melbourne, Australia. The show's format remained largely the same as previous seasons, with a few tweaks to the rules and presentation.

Panellists and Host
--------------------

The returning panel of judges consisted of Jackie O, Dannii Minogue, and Dave Hughes, while Urzila Carlson joined the show as a new panellist. The show was hosted by Osher Günsberg, who replaced previous host, Andrew O'Keefe.

Contestants

A total of 12 contestants competed in the season, each representing a unique character with their own backstory and costume. The contestants were:

* Fox

* Mirrorball

Dolly performed "Jolene" by Dolly Parton, and Dragonfly sang "Poker Face" by Lady Gaga. Fire Engine rounded out the episode with a performance of "We Will Rock You" by Queen. ### Episode 4 (14 August)

The fifth episode saw the return of Bravo, Dolly, and Dragonfly, as well as the introduction of Fire Engine's partner, Firefighter. ### Episode 7 (21 August)

The seventh episode saw the return of Bravo, Dolly, and Dragonfly, as well as the introduction of Sneezy Vampire's partner, Vampirella. Dolly performed "Respect" by Aretha Franklin, while the other contestants performed songs from various decades. The episode ended with the elimination of Sneezy Vampire.

### Episode 8 (22 August)

The eighth episode saw the return of Fox, Mirrorball, and Tiger, as well as the introduction of Lightning's partner, Thunder. Tiger performed "Umbrella" by Rihanna ft. Jay-Z, while the other contestants performed songs from various genres. The episode ended with the elimination of Lightning.

The ninth episode saw the return of Bravo, Dolly, and Dragonfly, as well as the introduction of Fire Engine's partner, Firefighter. Bravo performed "Roar" by Katy Perry, while the other contestants performed songs from various musicals. The episode ended with the elimination of Fire Engine.

### Episode 10 (24 August)

The tenth episode saw the return of Fox, Mirrorball, and Professor Pecan, as well as the introduction of Caterpillar's partner, Butterfly. Professor Pecan performed "We Are the Champions" by Queen, while the other contestants performed songs from various decades. The episode ended with the elimination of Professor Pecan.

### Episode 11 (28 August) - Finale

The season finale saw the remaining five contestants competing for the title of The Masked Singer. article:
Badin District

Badin District is an administrative division of the Sindh province of Pakistan. The district is located in the southeastern part of the province and is known for its rich cultural heritage and economic importance. The district is named after its capital city, Badin, which is a major urban center in the region.

# History

The history of Badin District dates back to the ancient Indus Valley Civilization, which flourished in the region over 4,000 years ago. The district was later inhabited by various tribes and empires, including the Arabs, Turks, and Mughals. In the 19th century, the district was part of the British Indian Empire and was a major center for trade and commerce.

After Pakistan gained independence in 1947, Badin District was created as a separate administrative division. The district has undergone significant changes and developments over the years, including the construction of infrastructure, expansion of education and healthcare facilities, and growth of industries.

# Demographics

Badin District has a population of over 1.1 million people, according to the 2017 census. The district has a diverse population, with various ethnic groups, including Sindhis, Balochis, and Mohajirs.

## Religion

The majority of the population in Badin District practices Islam, with over 90% of the population identifying as Muslim. The remaining 10% of the population belongs to other faiths, including Hinduism, Christianity, and Sikhism.

## Language

The main languages spoken in Badin District are Sindhi and Urdu. Other languages, including Balochi and Pashto, are also spoken by minority groups.

# Administration

Badin District is divided into several administrative sub-divisions, including tehsils, union councils, and dehs.

## List of Tehsils

The district is divided into five tehsils:

1. Badin Tehsil
2. Golarchi Tehsil
3. Matli Tehsil
4. Nindo Shahar Tehsil
5. Tando Bago Tehsil

## List of Union Councils

Each tehsil is further divided into union councils. There are a total of 45 union councils in the district.

## List of Dehs

The district is also divided into dehs, which are the smallest administrative units. There are over 300 dehs in the district.

# Education

Education is a major sector in Badin District, with a number of schools, colleges, and universities. The district has a literacy rate of over 50%, which is higher than the national average.

The district has a number of government and private schools, including primary, secondary, and higher secondary schools. There are also several colleges and universities in the district, including the University of Sindh, which has a campus in Badin.

# Economy

Badin District has a diverse economy, with a number of industries, including agriculture, manufacturing, and services.

## Railways

The district is connected to the rest of the country through a railway network. The Badin Railway Station is a major station on the Karachi-Hyderabad railway line.

## Badin Coal Field

The Badin Coal Field is a major coal reserve in the district. The coal field was discovered in the 1990s and has been mined since then. The coal field has an estimated reserve of over 1 billion tons of coal.

The district also has a number of other industries, including textiles, food processing, and construction materials. The district is also a major producer of agricultural products, including cotton, sugarcane, and fruits.

2022 Denmark Open

The 2022 Denmark Open was a badminton tournament that took place at the Odense Sports Park in Odense, Denmark, from October 18 to 23, 2022. It was the ninth tournament of the 2022 BWF World Tour and was part of the Denmark Open, which was first held in 1935.

# Tournament

## Venue
The Odense Sports Park was the venue for the 2022 Denmark Open. The stadium has a seating capacity of 2,200 and has hosted several international badminton tournaments in the past.

## Point distribution
The tournament followed the standard BWF point distribution system, with the winners of each event receiving 11,000 points, the runners-up receiving 9,350 points, and the semifinalists receiving 7,700 points.

article:
Hurricane Ian

Hurricane Ian was a devastating Category 5 hurricane that caused catastrophic damage and loss of life in the Caribbean and the southeastern United States in September 2022. The storm made landfall in Cuba and Florida, causing widespread destruction and flooding. Ian was the ninth named storm, fourth hurricane, and second major hurricane of the 2022 Atlantic hurricane season.

# Meteorological history

Ian formed as a tropical wave in the central Caribbean on September 19, 2022. The system gradually organized, and by September 23, it had developed into a tropical depression. The depression strengthened into Tropical Storm Ian later that day, and by September 24, it had become a hurricane. Ian rapidly intensified into a Category 3 hurricane on September 25, and by September 26, it had reached Category 4 strength. The storm continued to intensify, reaching Category 5 strength on September 27, with maximum sustained winds of 160 mph (260 km/h). Ian made landfall in Cuba's Pinar del Río Province later that day, causing widespread destruction and power outages. The storm emerged into the Gulf of Mexico on September 28, where it maintained its Category 4 strength. Ian made landfall in Florida on September 28, near Cayo Costa, causing catastrophic damage and flooding. The storm slowly weakened as it moved inland, eventually dissipating over North Carolina on October 1.

# Preparations

## Caribbean

### Jamaica

The Jamaican government issued a hurricane watch on September 22, as Ian was forecast to pass close to the island. The watch was upgraded to a hurricane warning on September 24, as the storm's projected path shifted closer to the island. The government ordered the closure of schools and government offices, and urged residents to stock up on supplies and prepare for the storm.

### Cayman Islands

The Cayman Islands government issued a hurricane warning on September 24, as Ian was forecast to pass close to the islands. The government ordered the closure of schools and government offices, and urged residents to prepare for the storm. A mandatory evacuation order was issued for the island of Little Cayman, and residents were advised to seek shelter in safe zones.

### Cuba

The Cuban government issued a hurricane warning on September 25, as Ian was forecast to make landfall in the western part of the island. The government ordered the evacuation of over 50,000 people, and urged residents to prepare for the storm. The government also activated its emergency response plan, which included the deployment of troops and emergency responders.

## United States

### Florida

The Florida government issued a state of emergency on September 23, as Ian was forecast to make landfall in the state. The governor ordered the activation of the state's emergency operations center, and urged residents to prepare for the storm. A mandatory evacuation order was issued for several counties, including Charlotte, Sarasota, and Lee. The governor also activated the Florida National Guard to assist with evacuations and storm response.

### Georgia

The Georgia government issued a state of emergency on September 26, as Ian was forecast to bring heavy rain and strong winds to the state. The governor ordered the activation of the state's emergency operations center, and urged residents to prepare for the storm.

### South Carolina

The South Carolina government issued a state of emergency on September 26, as Ian was forecast to bring heavy rain and strong winds to the state. The governor ordered the activation of the state's emergency operations center, and urged residents to prepare for the storm.

### Elsewhere

Other states, including North Carolina, Virginia, and Maryland, also issued states of emergency and prepared for the storm.

## The Bahamas

The Bahamian government issued a hurricane watch on September 27, as Ian was forecast to pass close to the islands. The watch was upgraded to a hurricane warning on September 28, as the storm's projected path shifted closer to the islands. The government ordered the closure of schools and government offices, and urged residents to prepare for the storm.

# Impact

## Caribbean

### Southern Caribbean and South America

Ian brought heavy rain and strong winds to several countries in the southern Caribbean and South America, including Trinidad and Tobago, Grenada, and Venezuela. The storm caused power outages and flooding in several areas.

### Cayman Islands

Ian passed close to the Cayman Islands on September 25, causing heavy rain and strong winds. The storm caused power outages and flooding in several areas, and several buildings were damaged.

### Cuba

Ian made landfall in Cuba's Pinar del Río Province on September 27, causing widespread destruction and power outages. The storm caused flooding in several areas, and several buildings were damaged or destroyed. The Cuban government reported that over 3 million people were affected by the storm.

## United States

### Florida

Ian made landfall in Florida on September 28, near Cayo Costa, causing catastrophic damage and flooding. The storm caused widespread power outages, and several buildings were damaged or destroyed. The storm surge caused flooding in several coastal areas, including Fort Myers and Cape Coral. The Florida government reported that over 2 million people were affected by the storm.

### The Carolinas

Ian brought heavy rain and strong winds to the Carolinas, causing power outages and flooding in several areas. The storm caused several roads to be closed, and several buildings were damaged.

### Elsewhere

Other states, including Georgia, Virginia, and Maryland, also experienced heavy rain and strong winds from Ian. The storm caused power outages and flooding in several areas, and several buildings were damaged.

# Aftermath

## Cuba

The Cuban government reported that over 3 million people were affected by the storm, and several areas were left without power or access to basic services. The government activated its emergency response plan, which included the deployment of troops and emergency responders. The government also established a relief fund to assist with recovery efforts.

## United States

### Damage estimates

The damage from Ian was estimated to be over $50 billion, making it one of the costliest hurricanes in U.S. history. The storm caused widespread destruction and flooding, and several areas were left without power or access to basic services.

# Depiction in media

Ian was widely covered in the media, with several news outlets providing live coverage of the storm's landfall and aftermath. The storm was also depicted in several social media posts and videos, which showed the storm's destructive power.

# Retirement

Due to the severity of the damage and loss of life caused by Ian, the name "Ian" was retired from the list of Atlantic hurricane names.

article:
Christianization of the Roman Empire as Diffusion of Innovation

The Christianization of the Roman Empire was a gradual process that spanned several centuries. Historians have traditionally approached this topic from a variety of perspectives, including social, cultural, and political lenses. However, a relatively new approach has emerged in recent years: network theory and diffusion of innovation. This framework views the spread of Christianity as a process of innovation diffusion, where the new faith was transmitted through social networks, influenced by various factors, and shaped by the characteristics of the innovation itself.

# Network theory and Diffusion of innovation as an approach

## Innovation

In the context of diffusion of innovation, an innovation refers to an idea, product, or practice that is perceived as new by the members of a social system. In the case of the Christianization of the Roman Empire, Christianity was the innovation that spread throughout the empire. This innovation was not just a set of beliefs, but also a new way of life, a new community, and a new set of practices.

## Alternative approaches

Other approaches to understanding the Christianization of the Roman Empire have focused on the role of emperors, the power of the church, or the appeal of Christian theology. While these perspectives have contributed to our understanding of the process, they have limitations. For example, they often overlook the agency of ordinary people, the role of social networks, and the complex interactions between different groups. In contrast, the diffusion of innovation approach emphasizes the dynamic and multifaceted nature of the process.

## Failure of diffusion

The Christianization of the Roman Empire was not a uniform or universal process. There were many areas where Christianity failed to diffuse, or where it was met with resistance. For example, in some parts of the empire, traditional pagan practices persisted, and Christianity was seen as a threat to local customs and traditions. Understanding the factors that contributed to the failure of diffusion can provide valuable insights into the complexities of the process.

# Five characteristics of diffusion

## Relative advantage

The relative advantage of an innovation refers to the degree to which it is perceived as better than existing alternatives. In the case of Christianity, its relative advantage lay in its promise of eternal life, its emphasis on compassion and forgiveness, and its offer of a sense of community and belonging.

### Alms

One of the key ways in which Christianity demonstrated its relative advantage was through the practice of alms-giving. Christians were encouraged to care for the poor, the sick, and the marginalized, which helped to build a sense of community and solidarity. This practice also helped to attract new converts, who were drawn to the Christian emphasis on compassion and charity.

### Slavery through the fifth century

Christianity also offered a relative advantage to slaves, who were a significant portion of the Roman population. Christian teachings emphasized the equality of all people before God, and the importance of treating others with kindness and respect. This helped to attract many slaves to the faith, who saw in it a way to escape the brutalities of their situation.

### Geography and a scale free network

The geography of the Roman Empire played a crucial role in the diffusion of Christianity. The empire's extensive network of roads, trade routes, and cities facilitated the movement of people, goods, and ideas. Christianity spread rapidly along these networks, often through the efforts of merchants, traders, and travelers. The scale-free nature of these networks, with their hubs and spokes, also helped to accelerate the diffusion process.

## Compatibility and complexity

The compatibility of an innovation refers to the degree to which it is consistent with existing values, norms, and practices. Christianity faced significant challenges in this regard, as it often conflicted with traditional Roman values and customs. However, the faith also demonstrated a remarkable ability to adapt and evolve, which helped to increase its compatibility with different social contexts.

## Trialability

The trialability of an innovation refers to the degree to which it can be tested or experimented with on a small scale before committing to it fully. Christianity offered a range of trialable practices and rituals, such as baptism, communion, and prayer, which helped to attract new converts.

### Reinvention

One of the key ways in which Christianity demonstrated its trialability was through the process of reinvention. As the faith spread to new areas and cultures, it was adapted and reinterpreted to fit local contexts. This helped to make Christianity more accessible and appealing to different groups of people.

## Observability

The observability of an innovation refers to the degree to which its results are visible to others. Christianity offered a range of observable practices and rituals, such as public worship, miracles, and healings, which helped to attract new converts and demonstrate the faith's relative advantage.

### Innovators of the first century

The first century CE saw the emergence of a group of innovators who played a crucial role in the diffusion of Christianity. These included the apostles, who spread the faith throughout the Mediterranean world, and the early Christian writers, who helped to articulate the theology and practices of the faith.

### Early adopters in the first and second centuries

The early adopters of Christianity were often drawn from the ranks of the educated and the wealthy. They were attracted to the faith's emphasis on reason, morality, and compassion, and they played a key role in spreading the faith to new areas and cultures.

### Third century early majority

The third century CE saw the emergence of an early majority of Christians, who were drawn from a wide range of social backgrounds. This group helped to establish Christianity as a major force in the Roman Empire, and they played a key role in shaping the faith's practices and institutions.

#### Sexual morality

One of the key areas in which the early majority of Christians made a significant impact was in the area of sexual morality. Christian teachings emphasized the importance of chastity, modesty, and fidelity, which helped to challenge traditional Roman attitudes towards sex and relationships.

#### Persecution

Despite the growing numbers of Christians, the faith faced significant persecution during the third century CE. This persecution helped to galvanize the Christian community, and it played a key role in shaping the faith's practices and institutions.

# Constantine as opinion leader

The conversion of Constantine in the early fourth century CE marked a significant turning point in the diffusion of Christianity. As the Roman Emperor, Constantine played a crucial role in promoting the faith, and his conversion helped to establish Christianity as the official religion of the empire.

# Notes

This article has provided an overview of the Christianization of the Roman Empire as a process of diffusion of innovation. By examining the characteristics of the innovation, the social networks through which it spread, and the factors that influenced its adoption, we can gain a deeper understanding of this complex and multifaceted process.

article:
Blonde (2022 film)

Blonde is a 2022 biographical drama film written and directed by Andrew Dominik, based on the 2000 novel of the same name by Joyce Carol Oates. The film is a fictionalized account of the life of Marilyn Monroe, played by Ana de Armas, and explores her struggles with fame, identity, and personal relationships. The film premiered at the 2022 Venice Film Festival and was later released on Netflix.

# Plot

The film is a non-linear narrative that blends fact and fiction to create a dreamlike portrayal of Marilyn Monroe's life. The story follows Marilyn from her childhood, where she is depicted as an illegitimate child, to her rise to fame as a Hollywood actress. Along the way, she struggles with her identity, her relationships, and the pressures of fame.

The film explores Marilyn's relationships with several men, including her husbands Joe DiMaggio and Arthur Miller, as well as her affairs with President John F. Kennedy and his brother Robert. These relationships are depicted as complex and often tumultuous, with Marilyn struggling to balance her desire for love and connection with her need for independence and self-preservation.

Throughout the film, Marilyn's mental and physical health are also explored, including her struggles with addiction and her experiences with traumatic events such as rape and abortion. These themes are woven throughout the narrative, creating a complex and nuanced portrait of a woman who was both iconic and vulnerable.

# Cast

* Ana de Armas as Marilyn Monroe
* Bobby Cannavale as Joe DiMaggio
* Adrien Brody as Arthur Miller
* Julianne Nicholson as Gladys Pearl Baker
* Xavier Samuel as Charles "Cass" Chaplin Jr.
* Evan Williams as Edward G. Robinson Jr.
* Toby Huss as Allan "Whitey" Snyder
* Sara Paxton as Miss Flynn
* Rebecca Wisocky as Yvet
* Caspar Phillipson as John F. Kennedy
* Dan Butler as I.E. Shinn
* Larry Sullivan as Norman Jefferies
* Monica Monroe as Jean Negulesco
* Tyrone Giordano as Richard Sherman

# Production

## Development and writing

The film was first announced in 2010, with Andrew Dominik set to write and direct. Dominik had previously directed the films Chopper and The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford, and was drawn to the project because of his fascination with Marilyn Monroe's life and legacy.

Dominik spent several years researching and writing the script, drawing on a range of sources including Joyce Carol Oates' novel, as well as Marilyn Monroe's own letters and diaries. He also consulted with experts and individuals who knew Marilyn, including her friends and colleagues.

## Pre-production

Pre-production on the film began in 2019, with Ana de Armas cast in the lead role. De Armas was a relatively unknown actress at the time, but Dominik was drawn to her because of her resemblance to Marilyn Monroe and her ability to convey a sense of vulnerability and sensitivity.

The film's production team also included cinematographer Chayse Irvin, production designer David Brisbin, and costume designer Jacqueline Durran. The team worked closely with Dominik to create a visual style that was both nostalgic and dreamlike, drawing on the iconography of 1950s and 1960s Hollywood.

## Casting

The film's cast was assembled over several months, with actors drawn from a range of backgrounds and disciplines. Bobby Cannavale and Adrien Brody were cast as Marilyn's husbands, Joe DiMaggio and Arthur Miller, while Julianne Nicholson played her mother, Gladys Pearl Baker.

The film also features a range of supporting actors, including Xavier Samuel, Evan Williams, and Toby Huss. These actors played a range of roles, from Marilyn's friends and colleagues to her lovers and adversaries.

## Filming

Filming on the movie took place over several months in 2020, with locations including Los Angeles, New York, and the Dominican Republic. The film's production team worked closely with Dominik to create a visual style that was both nostalgic and dreamlike, drawing on the iconography of 1950s and 1960s Hollywood.

The film's cinematographer, Chayse Irvin, used a range of techniques to create a sense of intimacy and immediacy, including handheld camera work and natural lighting. The film's production designer, David Brisbin, also worked closely with Dominik to create a sense of period authenticity, drawing on archival materials and historical research.

## Music

The film's score was composed by Nick Cave and Warren Ellis, who have previously worked together on a range of film and television projects. The score is a mix of original music and period songs, and features a range of instruments including piano, guitar, and strings.

The film's soundtrack also includes a range of period songs, including music by Ella Fitzgerald, Billie Holiday, and Frank Sinatra. These songs are used to create a sense of period authenticity, and to evoke the glamour and sophistication of 1950s and 1960s Hollywood.

# Release

Blonde premiered at the 2022 Venice Film Festival, where it received a mixed response from critics. The film was later released on Netflix, where it became one of the platform's most-watched titles.

# Reception

## Critical response

The film received a mixed response from critics, with some praising its visual style and performances, while others criticized its narrative and tone. The film holds a 44% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, based on 223 reviews, with an average rating of 5.2/10.

On Metacritic, the film has a score of 51 out of 100, based on 56 reviews, indicating "mixed or average" reviews. Some critics praised the film's performances, particularly Ana de Armas' portrayal of Marilyn Monroe, while others criticized the film's narrative and tone.

## Industry reception

The film was also met with a mixed response from industry professionals, with some praising its ambition and scope, while others criticized its execution and tone. The film's director, Andrew Dominik, was praised for his visual style and attention to detail, while the film's cast, particularly Ana de Armas, was praised for their performances.

## Cast

The film's cast, particularly Ana de Armas, received widespread praise for their performances. De Armas was praised for her portrayal of Marilyn Monroe, which was seen as nuanced and sensitive. The film's supporting cast, including Bobby Cannavale and Adrien Brody, was also praised for their performances.

## NC-17 rating

The film received an NC-17 rating from the Motion Picture Association of America (MPAA) due to its graphic content, including scenes of sex, nudity, and violence. The film's director, Andrew Dominik, was critical of the rating, arguing that it was unfair and would limit the film's audience.

## Criticism about depiction of abortion

The film was also criticized for its depiction of abortion, with some critics arguing that it was graphic and disturbing. The film's director, Andrew Dominik, defended the scene, arguing that it was necessary to convey the trauma and pain that Marilyn Monroe experienced.

## Accolades

Despite the mixed response, the film received several awards and nominations, including several Academy Award nominations. Ana de Armas was nominated for Best Actress, while the film's costume designer, Jacqueline Durran, was nominated for Best Costume Design.

article:
Tony Bennett
================

Anthony Dominick Benedetto, known professionally as Tony Bennett, was an American singer of popular music, standards, and jazz. With a career spanning over seven decades, Bennett was one of the most enduring and iconic figures in the music industry. He was known for his smooth, velvety voice, impeccable phrasing, and interpretive skills, which allowed him to connect with audiences across generations.

Early life
-----------

### 1926–1943: Family and education

Tony Bennett was born on August 3, 1926, in Long Island City, Queens, New York, to Ann (née Suraci) and John Benedetto. His father was a tailor, and his mother was a seamstress. Bennett grew up in a family of Italian-American descent and was raised in a culturally rich environment that valued music and the arts. He began singing at a young age and was influenced by jazz musicians such as Louis Armstrong and Billie Holiday.

Bennett attended the High School of Industrial Art in Manhattan, where he studied music and painting. After graduating in 1944, he began performing in local clubs and restaurants, singing with various jazz and pop bands.

### 1944–1950: World War II and after

In 1944, Bennett was drafted into the United States Army during World War II. He served in the infantry and was stationed in Germany, where he participated in the liberation of a concentration camp. After the war, Bennett was honorably discharged and returned to the United States.

In the late 1940s, Bennett began performing in New York City's jazz clubs, where he was discovered by Bob Hope. Hope took Bennett under his wing, and the young singer began touring with Hope's troupe, performing for American servicemen.

Career
--------

### 1951–1959: First successes

In 1951, Bennett signed with Columbia Records and released his first single, "Because of You." The song became a huge success, reaching the top of the Billboard charts and staying there for 10 weeks. Bennett's subsequent singles, including "Rags to Riches" and "Stranger in Paradise," also became hits.

In the early 1950s, Bennett began performing on television, appearing on shows such as "The Ed Sullivan Show" and "The Tonight Show." He also started touring, performing in concert halls and nightclubs across the United States.

### 1954–1965: A growing artistry

In the mid-1950s, Bennett began to develop his unique style, which blended jazz, pop, and standards. He released several successful albums, including "Cloud 7" and "The Beat of My Heart," which featured his interpretations of jazz classics.

In the early 1960s, Bennett began to explore new musical directions, incorporating elements of rock and roll and folk into his music. He released several albums during this period, including "I Left My Heart in San Francisco" and "What the World Needs Now Is Love."

### 1965–1979: Years of struggle

In the late 1960s and 1970s, Bennett's popularity began to wane. He struggled with personal demons, including a cocaine addiction, and his music fell out of favor with the changing tastes of the times.

Despite these challenges, Bennett continued to perform and record, releasing several albums during this period. However, it wasn't until the late 1970s that he began to experience a resurgence in popularity.

### 1979–1989: Turnaround

In 1979, Bennett's son, Danny, took over as his manager and helped him to revamp his image and sound. Bennett released several successful albums during this period, including "The Art of Excellence" and "Bennett/Berlin."

In the 1980s, Bennett began to perform with younger artists, including Sting and Billy Joel. He also started touring again, performing in concert halls and festivals around the world.

### 1990–2006: Established career

In the 1990s, Bennett's career experienced a full-fledged revival. He released several critically acclaimed albums, including "Perfectly Frank" and "Steppin' Out," which won him several Grammy Awards.

Bennett continued to tour and perform, appearing on television and in concert halls around the world. He also began to paint again, exhibiting his artwork in galleries and museums.

### 2006–2021: Later years and final album

In the 2000s, Bennett continued to release new music and tour. He released several successful albums, including "Duets: An American Classic" and "Cheek to Cheek," a collaboration with Lady Gaga.

In 2021, Bennett released his final album, "Love for Sale," a collaboration with Lady Gaga. The album was a critical and commercial success, and Bennett performed a farewell concert at Radio City Music Hall in New York City.

article:
Ștefan Foriș

Ștefan Foriș was a Romanian communist politician who served as the General Secretary of the Romanian Communist Party (PCR) from 1944 to 1945. His tenure was marked by significant events, including the PCR's outlawing, the adoption of the "popular front" tactic, and the party's eventual takeover of power. Foriș's life and legacy are complex and multifaceted, reflecting the tumultuous period in which he lived.

#Biography

##Early life

Ștefan Foriș was born on May 23, 1892, in Hordou, a village in the Austro-Hungarian Empire (now part of Romania). His family was of peasant origin, and Foriș received limited formal education. However, he quickly became involved in socialist politics, joining the Romanian Social Democratic Party in 1909. Foriș's early activism focused on issues related to workers' rights and social inequality.

##PCR outlawing

In 1921, Foriș participated in the founding of the Romanian Communist Party (PCR), which was subsequently outlawed by the Romanian government in 1924. Foriș was among the party leaders who continued to operate clandestinely, maintaining connections with other communist organizations across Europe. During this period, Foriș developed strong ties with the Soviet Union and the Comintern, which would later influence his policies as PCR leader.

##"Popular front" tactic

In the mid-1930s, Foriș played a key role in adopting the "popular front" tactic, a strategy aimed at uniting various left-wing and liberal forces against the growing threat of fascism. This approach involved forming alliances with non-communist parties and organizations, which helped to increase the PCR's visibility and influence. Foriș's advocacy for the popular front tactic brought him closer to the Soviet Union's leadership, who saw it as an effective means of countering fascist expansion in Europe.

##Taking over

In 1944, Foriș became the General Secretary of the PCR, a position that allowed him to shape the party's policies and direction. As the Allies advanced against Axis forces, Foriș saw an opportunity for the PCR to take power in Romania. He skillfully navigated the complex web of alliances and rivalries between various political groups, eventually securing the PCR's position as a dominant force in the country.

##Resisting the resistance

Foriș's leadership was marked by a willingness to confront and suppress opposition from within and outside the PCR. He resisted efforts by other communist factions to challenge his authority, often using his connections with the Soviet Union to consolidate his position. Foriș also faced resistance from non-communist groups, including liberals and conservatives, who saw the PCR's rise to power as a threat to their interests.

##Caransebeș conspiracy

In 1945, Foriș was implicated in the Caransebeș conspiracy, a plot to overthrow the Romanian government and install a communist regime. The conspiracy was discovered, and Foriș was forced to flee into hiding to avoid arrest. Although he managed to evade capture initially, Foriș was eventually caught and brought to trial.

##Capture

Foriș's capture was a significant blow to the PCR, which was still consolidating its power in Romania. His arrest and trial were widely publicized, with the government using the opportunity to discredit the PCR and its leaders. Foriș's imprisonment marked a turning point in his life, as he was subjected to harsh treatment and interrogation.

##Killing

On May 6, 1946, Ștefan Foriș died in prison under unclear circumstances. The official account stated that he took his own life, but rumors persisted that he had been murdered or tortured to death. Foriș's killing marked the end of an era for the PCR, as his successors would go on to shape the party's policies and direction in the years to come.

#Legacy

##Cover-up and rumors

Foriș's death sparked a wave of speculation and conspiracy theories, with many believing that he had been killed to silence him or prevent him from revealing secrets about the PCR's leadership. The government's handling of the investigation and the official account of Foriș's death only fueled these rumors, which continue to circulate to this day.

##Rehabilitation

In the years following Foriș's death, his legacy underwent a significant transformation. As the PCR solidified its grip on power in Romania, Foriș was rehabilitated as a hero of the communist movement. His contributions to the party's development and his role in the popular front tactic were celebrated, and he was remembered as a dedicated and principled leader.

#Personal life and family

Ștefan Foriș married twice and had two children. His family life was marked by the challenges and hardships faced by many communist activists during the interwar period. Foriș's relationships with his family members were often strained due to his intense focus on politics and his frequent periods of imprisonment.

article:
Telangana Legislative Assembly

The Telangana Legislative Assembly, also known as the Telangana Vidhan Sabha, is the lower house of the state legislature of Telangana, one of the 28 states of India. The assembly is composed of 119 members, who are elected by the people of Telangana through a general election, using a first-past-the-post system. The Telangana Legislative Assembly plays a crucial role in the governance of the state, and its members are responsible for making laws, approving the state budget, and holding the government accountable for its actions.

#History

The Telangana Legislative Assembly was formed on June 2, 2014, after the state of Telangana was separated from the state of Andhra Pradesh. The first session of the assembly was held on June 9, 2014, and K. Chandrashekar Rao was elected as the first Chief Minister of Telangana. The assembly has a rich history, with several notable events and milestones, including the passage of the Telangana State Formation Act in 2013, which paved the way for the creation of the new state.

#Election Process

The election process for the Telangana Legislative Assembly is governed by the Representation of the People Act, 1951, and the Conduct of Elections Rules, 1961. The elections are conducted by the Election Commission of India, an independent and impartial body responsible for ensuring the integrity of the electoral process. The assembly elections are held every five years, unless dissolved earlier by the Governor on the advice of the Chief Minister. The elections are contested by candidates from various political parties, as well as independent candidates. The voters of Telangana participate in the election process by casting their votes for their preferred candidates.

#Composition

##Presiding officers

The Telangana Legislative Assembly has two presiding officers: the Speaker and the Deputy Speaker. The Speaker is the presiding officer of the assembly and is responsible for maintaining order and decorum in the house. The Speaker is also responsible for interpreting the rules and procedures of the assembly and for ensuring that the members of the assembly adhere to the code of conduct. The Deputy Speaker assists the Speaker in the discharge of his duties and presides over the assembly in the absence of the Speaker.

##Members

The Telangana Legislative Assembly is composed of 119 members, who are elected by the people of Telangana through a general election. The members of the assembly represent the various constituencies of Telangana and are responsible for representing the interests of their constituents. The members of the assembly are also responsible for participating in debates and discussions on various issues, for moving motions and resolutions, and for voting on bills and other legislation.

#List of the assemblies

The Telangana Legislative Assembly has had several assemblies since its formation in 2014. The following is a list of the assemblies:

* 1st Telangana Legislative Assembly (2014-2018)
* 2nd Telangana Legislative Assembly (2018-present)

#Members of Legislative Assembly

The members of the Telangana Legislative Assembly are elected by the people of Telangana through a general election. The members are responsible for representing the interests of their constituents and for participating in the legislative process. The following are some of the notable members of the Telangana Legislative Assembly:

* K. Chandrashekar Rao, Chief Minister of Telangana
* Kadiyam Srihari, Deputy Chief Minister of Telangana
* T. Harish Rao, Minister for Irrigation and Legislative Affairs

* Andhra Pradesh Legislative Assembly
* Government of Telangana
* Politics of Telangana
* Telangana State Formation Act, 2013

#Notes

The Telangana Legislative Assembly plays a crucial role in the governance of the state of Telangana. The assembly is responsible for making laws, approving the state budget, and holding the government accountable for its actions. The members of the assembly are elected by the people of Telangana and are responsible for representing the interests of their constituents.

2023 Korea Open (badminton)

The 2023 Korea Open was a badminton tournament that took place at the Palma Stadium in Suncheon, South Korea, from April 18 to April 23, 2023. The tournament was a part of the 2023 BWF World Tour and was the fifth tournament of the 2023 BWF World Tour.

# Tournament

## Venue

The 2023 Korea Open was held at the Palma Stadium in Suncheon, South Korea. The Palma Stadium is an indoor stadium that has a seating capacity of 5,000 spectators.

article:
Timeline of Sydney

Sydney, the capital of New South Wales and the largest city in Australia, has a rich and diverse history spanning thousands of years. From its pre-colonial origins as a place of gathering for the indigenous Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, to its current status as a global hub for culture, finance, and innovation, Sydney has evolved significantly over time. This article provides a comprehensive timeline of the major events and developments that have shaped the city of Sydney.

# Pre-Colonial

For at least 30,000 years, the area now known as Sydney has been inhabited by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples. The indigenous people of the region, including the Eora, Dharug, and Gundungurra tribes, lived in harmony with the land, relying on its natural resources for food, shelter, and spiritual practices. The arrival of European explorers in the late 18th century would have a profound impact on the lives of these indigenous peoples, forever changing the course of Sydney's history.

# 18th–19th centuries

## 1770s–1790s

In 1770, British explorer James Cook arrived in Sydney Cove, marking the beginning of European settlement in the area. The British government, seeking to establish a penal colony, sent the First Fleet to Sydney in 1788, under the command of Captain Arthur Phillip. The fleet arrived on January 26, 1788, and the city of Sydney was officially founded. The early years of the colony were marked by struggle and hardship, as the British settlers faced challenges in establishing a sustainable food supply and dealing with the harsh Australian climate.

## 1800s–1840s

During the early 19th century, Sydney began to grow and develop, with the establishment of a thriving port and the construction of key infrastructure, including the Sydney Harbour Bridge's predecessor, the Dawes Point Battery. The city's population swelled, driven by the arrival of free settlers and the growth of the wool and wheat industries. In 1821, the New South Wales Government established the Sydney Mechanics' School of Arts, one of the city's first educational institutions.

## 1850s–1890s

The mid-19th century saw significant growth and transformation in Sydney, driven by the discovery of gold in the nearby Blue Mountains in 1851. The gold rush brought a surge of new arrivals to the city, and Sydney's population grew rapidly. The city's infrastructure expanded to meet the needs of its growing population, with the establishment of a tram network, the construction of the Sydney Observatory, and the development of the city's iconic Bondi Beach.

# 20th century

## 1900s–1940s

The early 20th century saw Sydney continue to grow and develop, with the establishment of new industries, including manufacturing and finance. The city played a significant role in Australia's contribution to World War I, with many Sydneysiders serving overseas. In the 1920s and 1930s, Sydney experienced a cultural renaissance, with the establishment of the Sydney Symphony Orchestra and the development of the city's vibrant theatre scene.

## 1950s–1990s

In the post-war period, Sydney experienced rapid growth and transformation, driven by the arrival of migrants from Europe and the Asia-Pacific region. The city hosted the 1956 Summer Olympics, which brought international attention and investment to the city. In the 1960s and 1970s, Sydney's cultural scene continued to thrive, with the establishment of the Sydney Opera House and the development of the city's vibrant music and arts scenes.

# 21st century

## 2000s

In the 21st century, Sydney has continued to evolve and grow, with a focus on sustainability, innovation, and cultural diversity. The city hosted the 2000 Summer Olympics, which brought significant investment and attention to the city. In the 2000s, Sydney's cultural scene continued to thrive, with the establishment of new museums, galleries, and performance venues.

## 2010s

In the 2010s, Sydney experienced significant growth and development, driven by the expansion of the city's finance and technology sectors. The city's infrastructure continued to evolve, with the establishment of new transport links, including the Sydney Light Rail. In 2015, Sydney hosted the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors Meeting, which brought international attention to the city.

## 2020s

In the 2020s, Sydney continues to evolve and grow, with a focus on sustainability, innovation, and cultural diversity. The city is currently undergoing significant transformation, with the development of new infrastructure, including the Sydney Metro and the Western Sydney Airport. As the city looks to the future, it is clear that Sydney will continue to play a significant role as a global hub for culture, finance, and innovation.
